What if plants could follow you online?
Here’s the story on how I got my houseplants to set their social media profiles (sorta).

Prototypes are my favorite activity and part of the design process, and I feel that every time I start a prototype, something completely different comes out, which is even better than I had hoped. There are very few other ways to get as much learning in a short time than from building prototypes for your ideas.

Yesterday, I woke up feeling exhausted after a week of reading and writing a lot, I thought to myself, that for whatever I was going to do today, I would want someone else to create all the content for me. That someone else was AI in this case, and that thing was a social media profile for houseplants.
My houseplants, a strong bunch
https://miro.medium.com/max/2888/1*nXDnQ7xBGY6NfYBGgopeKg.png

While folding the laundry, I started to think about my houseplants and how the ones I have now are the strong ones that survived without much care. I realized that some that didn’t make it weren’t fit for my apartment and care style — consisting mostly of watering them. So I thought about immortalizing this particular group of survivors and wondered if other people who have the same kind of plants could help me find a greater variety of species that would survive in my house.
But photos weren’t enough to set my plan in motion, I had to know more about these green warriors to connect with others.
Tell me more about you
https://miro.medium.com/max/1844/0*ODVuevnb4j-ZdUWv

Since plants can’t talk, and I also don’t want to do any content creation work today, I figured I’d had computer vision help me tag my plants. I used the Vision AI API to generate tags for my plants based on the photos. This would allow me to categorize them, and I could use the generated tags to find more information. Remember, I still don’t want to create any content, if possible.
Don’t leaf me alone!
https://miro.medium.com/max/2448/0*FqRH21R3f8RBFvyK
Now that my plants had tags, I realized they’d be alone and friendless unless I could find other similar plants. That would also help to get more tags and correct some that might be off.
I fetched similar images of plants from the Vision AI API and it seemed like I was still getting away with my plan of not creating content.
Can’t make friends without knowing their names
https://miro.medium.com/max/2464/0*8lf9Id1RkuLnseWD
https://miro.medium.com/max/2416/0*VB_4Q3sSikFHU-7V

At this point, I had a nice profile set for my plants, but our silent housemates would need names to find and connect with those other plant owners. I figured there had to be a service that would generate names by entering the tags or keywords. A quick google search and I was looking at a service called Namelix, which solved my plant name problem reasonably fast.
Plants need bios
https://miro.medium.com/max/2960/0*D-U1Mx9cWETSccCf
I realized that my plants couldn’t generate content, but I wasn’t going to let their profiles go empty; after all, I was way past my initial goal and into the dark side of my prototypes.
I used Rapidminer to extract random bios from Twitter users, draw nouns, and create a replacement map with the tags. The result was a list of potential bios for my plants.
Now we’re talking.
https://miro.medium.com/max/1532/0*dVH0J9WrWEc0Dtq4
No posts, no followers

Now that my plants had somewhat of a personality, they had to also have a voice. What could I possibly do to create their social media posts? I figured it would be easy to use their new shiny bios and generate content based on that. Cue Talk to Transformer, a service that will create content using a neural network to complete text.
https://miro.medium.com/max/1928/0*zLlI10V060j09OHe
Will these houseplants try to sell you Herbalife products on social media?

Just so that they don’t spend too much time online and veer off the good path, I’ve figured I’d give my plants jobs. Using Brand Mark, a service to generate professional logos for business, I created possible employers for my oxygen-giving friends.
https://miro.medium.com/max/2824/1*iCUR3zFIXouPBB7Sq7Ru4Q.png
The end result
https://miro.medium.com/max/5300/1*yyoBjgU5FVf80V5CGuDGOQ.png
Get to know my lovely plants and their profiles.
What I’ve learned from being lazy about content creation

I was amazed at how much I could generate from this short experiment. I probably tested around 20 generators and APIs I had no idea about and feel that I understand more about what’s happening right now in terms of AI-assisted content generation.

I believe this information will come handy later at some project, or maybe when I feel lazy again in the future. I see a lot of potentials for generating novel prototypes or as an activity for someone trying to learn more about AI.
Do you know any other content generators? I’m still trying to figure out how to get the plants to talk to each other, but maybe that’ll stay for another day.
Thanks for reading, and remember to water your plants.
